Lastly, Occam‚Äôs Razor. ‚ÄúThis convenient rule-of-thumb urges us when faced with two hypotheses that explain the data equally well to choose the simpler.‚Äù
(9/12)

‚ÄúQuantify.‚Äù

The act of quantification makes evaluating the legitimacy of a claim far more tractable as ‚Äúwhat is vague and qualitative is open to many explanations.‚Äù When evaluating a claim, try to see what data is available to support it.  
(8/12)

‚ÄùSpin more than one hypothesis.‚Äù

Consider the variety of ways something can be explained  and think of how you could disprove each of these. The hypotheses that survive this process of Darwinian selection are more likely to be right.
(7/12)

‚ÄúTry not to get overly attached to a hypothesis just because it‚Äôs yours.‚Äù 

Confirmation bias is perhaps the most pernicious bias. When considering an idea, reflect on whether you want it to be true. Actively seek out arguments against it or plausible alternatives. 
(6/12)

‚ÄúAlways ask whether the hypothesis can be, at least in principle, falsified.‚Äù 

The Principle of Falsification was first proposed by philosopher of science Karl Popper: a theory must have a means for it to be proved wrong to be considered legitimate.
(5/12)

‚Äù[A]rguments from authority carry little weight ‚Äî ‚Äúauthorities‚Äù have made mistakes in the past.‚Äù 

Due to this, we should ‚Äú[e]ncourage substantive debate on the evidence by knowledgeable proponents of all points of view.‚Äù
(4/12) https://t.co/Tx6Pt1Kp66

‚ÄúWherever possible there must be independent confirmation of the ‚Äòfacts.‚Äô‚Äù

One person‚Äôs facts are another person‚Äôs fiction. To help distinguish the two in your mental model of the world, seek out other sources of evidence for a claim.
(3/12)

‚ÄúIf there‚Äôs a chain of argument, every link in the chain must work (including the premise)‚Äînot just most of them.‚Äù

To evaluate ideas and assess what is sound and what is baloney we need to be able to understand the underlying logic (or lack of it).
